titleStmt.title: How Coyote Would Have Liked to Have Eaten Stinkbug

projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from a narrator who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

body.p: One day, Stinkbug was sitting on the road. Coyote was coming along the road, and as he was arriving to where Stinkbug was, he looked down and said to him, "What would FriendThe word hamiigo is not a common one in the Seri language and so its use by Coyote is interesting. He uses it here without a definite article, but is not using it as a vocative, it seems, since there is no indication of second person in the sentence. It is not taken here and in the next sentence as a vocative, unlike four paragraphs below. The word "is" in this sentence is also not at all common (it was not included in the dictionary), but is not restricted to Coyote speech. be doing here? I think I'd like to chew on Friend. Hmmm," he said.
Stinkbug replied: "I'm just here doing something," he said.
Then Coyote said: "What would he be doing?"
[Stinkbug:] "The underground dwellers are talking, and I am here listening to them."
[Coyote:] "Friend, what are they saying? If you understand what they are saying, don't hide it from me!"

[Stinkbug:] "OKThis word is very unusual and, if included in a dictionary, would be an interjection (although followed by a declarative enclitic here). It has a nasalized vowel that is otherwise unexplained phonologically.. Can that be it? Can that be the meaning of it? How could they be thinking and talking like that?This sentence is a bit more complex in the recording but is not clear."

Then he continued: "Everything that defecatesThe verb translated 'defecate' here is considered very vulgar today and was only slightly less vulgar fifty years ago. on road will be gathered together and killed, they say."
[Coyote:] "Well, in that case, I am going to run away."
And at that point, he took off running. While he was still with Stinkbug, Coyote took off running, and Stinkbug escaped into a conveniently found burrow.
Anyone who sees Coyote tricks him. Stinkbug had tricked him and escaped. The end.
